thought: The certificate information shows that the domain has a certificate issued by Let's Encrypt, which is a legitimate certificate authority. The presence of a valid SSL certificate does not indicate whether a site is a scam or not, as many scam sites also use SSL to appear trustworthy. The certificate is also very new, which is consistent with the new domain registration. This information alone is not enough to determine the site's legitimacy. I should look for user feedback or reports about this website online.

[{'url': 'https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2024/01/04/weight-loss-product-scams/72094510007/', 'content': "How to spot false promises
Here are some tips from the FTC on how to spot false promises:
Avoid fraud:Make these 5 New Year's resolutions to avoid scams this year
More ways to spot weight-loss scams
Here’s some additional tips from the BBB on how to spot the weight-loss scams:
Betty Lin-Fisher is a consumer reporter for USA TODAY. At the start of the new year, consumers hear a lot of “new year, new you” advertising around health and fitness products, according to the Federal Trade Commission.
 The same goes for the dramatic “before” and “after” pictures, said the FTC: Scammers often use stock or altered photographs, not photos of people who used what they’re trying to sell you.
 Go on a search engine and type in the name of the product and “review” or “scam” to see what pops up.
 It’s the new year and with that comes weight-loss scams promising to miraculously melt away the pounds – without exercise or a special diet.
"}, {'url': 'https://www.scamadviser.com/check-website/cloverscar.life', 'content': 'The trust score of cloverscar.life is very low. Why? The trust score of cloverscar.life is extremely low. This is a strong indicator that the website may be a scam. We rated cloverscar.life using a computer program. The algorithm has scanned the website looking at the source code being used, terms and conditions, registry, location of the company and if the website has received many positive ...'}, {'url': 'https://www.reddit.com/r/Scams/comments/a8gqnm/my_spidey_sense_is_telling_me_that_this_is_a/', 'content': 'This is a common and major SCAM! I read about this in detail on scamwarners and the exact same thing happened to the guy but the difference was, he KNEW it was a scam and messed with the scammers for days.. The check will be fake or they will use a stolen credit card to pay you, or some method of payment where it can be reversed.'}, {'url': 'https://www.scamvoid.net/', 'content': 'Find a list of most viewed website reports of this month. Use this service to check the online reputation of a website, check if a website is safe or a scam, check if a website is safe to buy from, check if a website is legit and trusted by other users.'}, {'url': 'https://www.bbb.org/all/social-media-scams/think-twice-before-buying-from-these-social-media-ads', 'content': 'How the scam works
Look out for these common scams reported to BBB Scam Tracker:
Products that claim to support charity:
As you scroll through your Facebook or Instagram feed, you see an ad from a small business selling adorable jewelry, t-shirts, or other merchandise. In fact, the\xa02022 BBB Online Scams Report\xa0found that online purchase scams were the most common cons reported to Scam Tracker and the category with the most victims.
 Before you sign up for these “limited time offers,” research the company online, see if there are any other consumer complaints, and read the terms and conditions you agree to carefully. Check the “About Us” or “Contact Us” information on the company’s website to see if they contain actual contact details for the business. If you purchase any of these products, you may risk not only receiving a poor quality product, but it may not meet environmental and safety regulations either.
See more about\xa0counterfeit product scams.
'}]

The website claims to be aware of fake sites impersonating them, a tactic that could be used to appear legitimate while being a scam itself. The domain was recently registered, which is common for scam websites. The WHOIS information has redacted details, preventing verification of the company's legitimacy.
